fullDescription.text:
Apache Commons BeanUtils introduced a fix for BDSA-2014-0001 (CVE-2014-0114), however did not enable the protections by default. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause code execution in applications that did not use the new security feature.The Struts 1 ActionForm object allowed access to the `class` parameter, which is directly mapped to the `getClass()` method. A remote attacker could use this flaw to manipulate the `ClassLoader` used by an application server running Struts 1. This could lead to remote code execution under certain conditions, allowing unauthorised disclosure of information, unauthorised modification and disruption of service.

Apache Commons BeanUtils is distributed in `lib/commons-beanutils-1.8.0.jar` in Apache Struts **1.x** to **1.3.10** and in other products requiring commons-beanutils (to version **1.9.2**)

fullDescription.text: Apache Commons contains a flaw that is due to the Base32 codec decoding  invalid strings instead of rejecting them. This may allow a remote attacker to tunnel  additional information via a base 32 string that seems valid.

fullDescription.text: The apache commons collection (ACC) library, when utilized in an application that deserializes untrusted user input, is vulnerable to a remote attacker executing arbitrary code.Apache Common Collections and Apache Synapse contain a vulnerability that allows for remote code execution (RCE) via crafted specialized objects. Failed attempts will cause a denial of service (DoS) attack.Apache Commons Collection is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) due to the unsafe handling of in-memory data structures. A remote attacker could execute arbitrary code on the underlying system by submitting crafted data packets to a vulnerable server.Apache Commons Collections has a security flaw in the `InvokeTransformer` class whereby serializable collections can be built that execute arbitrary Java code.  An attacker can achieve remote code execution (*RCE*) when untrusted user-provided objects are deserialized by applications that use Commons Collections.

## CVE, BDSA IDs
CVEIDs 

BDSAIDs BDSA-2015-0753 BDSA-2017-2285 BDSA-2015-0766 BDSA-2015-0001

## Description
The apache commons collection (ACC) library, when utilized in an application that deserializes untrusted user input, is vulnerable to a remote attacker executing arbitrary code.Apache Common Collections and Apache Synapse contain a vulnerability that allows for remote code execution (RCE) via crafted specialized objects. Failed attempts will cause a denial of service (DoS) attack.Apache Commons Collection is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) due to the unsafe handling of in-memory data structures. A remote attacker could execute arbitrary code on the underlying system by submitting crafted data packets to a vulnerable server.Apache Commons Collections has a security flaw in the `InvokeTransformer` class whereby serializable collections can be built that execute arbitrary Java code.  An attacker can achieve remote code execution (*RCE*) when untrusted user-provided objects are deserialized by applications that use Commons Collections.The apache commons collection (ACC) library, when utilized in an application that deserializes untrusted user input, is vulnerable to a remote attacker executing arbitrary code.Apache Common Collections and Apache Synapse contain a vulnerability that allows for remote code execution (RCE) via crafted specialized objects. Failed attempts will cause a denial of service (DoS) attack.Apache Commons Collection is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) due to the unsafe handling of in-memory data structures. A remote attacker could execute arbitrary code on the underlying system by submitting crafted data packets to a vulnerable server.Apache Commons Collections has a security flaw in the `InvokeTransformer` class whereby serializable collections can be built that execute arbitrary Java code.  An attacker can achieve remote code execution (*RCE*) when untrusted user-provided objects are deserialized by applications that use Commons Collections.

## Upgrade Guidance

Short Term  3.2.2

Long Term 20040616

fullDescription.text:
Apache Commons FileUpload was discovered to be vulnerable to NULL byte poisoning due to the incorrect handling of filenames containing NULL bytes. The failure to check for NULL byte allows a remote unauthenticated attacker to upload or overwrite files on the system leading to unauthorized file modification, denial-of-service or remote code execution (RCE).Apache Commons FileUpload does not sufficiently limit the the number of request parts that can be received via user input. An attacker can exploit this flaw by supplying a malicious upload or series of uploads and cause excessive resource allocation. This can trigger a denial-of-service (DoS).

**Note:** This vulnerability was not properly fixed in Apache Tomcat and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2023-28709** (**BDSA-2023-1242**). The fix for Apache Commons FileUpload was not affected.Apache Commons FileUpload is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) due to unsafe deserialization of Java objects. This could allow an attacker to write, copy and delete arbitrary files on a target system within the privileges of the application.

The fix for Apache Commons FileUpload was not affected.Apache Commons FileUpload is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) due to unsafe deserialization of Java objects. This could allow an attacker to write, copy and delete arbitrary files on a target system within the privileges of the application.

Long Term 1.5

fullDescription.text:
Apache Log4j is vulnerable to a remote code execution (RCE) issue due to how the Apache Chainsaw component can unsafely deserialize user controlled input.

An attacker could send crafted input to the application in order to abuse the flaw and execute malicious code on the system.

**Note**: The Apache Chainsaw deserialization vulnerability has been reported as **CVE-2020-9493** and affects EOL Apache Log4j **1.2.x** versions that include this component.Apache Log4j **1.2.x** versions are vulnerable to SQL injection (SQLi). This may allow an attacker to insert SQL queries into messages being logged that will get executed against a backend database. 

**Note:** This issue  affects versions **1.2.x** that are configured to use the `JDBCAppender`. The vendor states that Log4j 1 is no longer maintained and this issue will not be fixed.Log4j is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) due to the deserialization of untrusted data. An attacker that is able to make the JMSSink component submit requests to a given LDAP server could load malicious Java classes into the vulnerable application's memory by leveraging the JNDI class-loading capability.

In order to exploit this vulnerability, the attacker must be able to control the configuration of Log4j, or must have access to an LDAP server which the JMSSink component is configured to use. Log4j must also be configured to utilize JMSSink, which is not used by default.Apache chainsaw is vulnerable to a deserialization of untrusted data flaw. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause remote code execution (RCE).Log4j **1.x** versions are vulnerable to deserializing untrusted data if configured to use `JMSAppender` (which is not the default). A remote attacker could leverage this to execute arbitrary code on the underlying system with the privileges of the application that is running Log4j.

**Note** that Log4j **1.x** has been marked EOL for many years and has not received updates in this time.Apache Log4j is vulnerable to man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks due to improper SSL certificate validation due to host name mismatch. An attacker could exploit this by mounting a man-in-the-middle attack which could leak log messages sent through SMTPS.Apache Log4j is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE).  This allows a remote attacker to send a crafted serialized payload that, when processed by Log4j, will execute arbitrary code. This can occur if Log4j is deserializing untrusted network traffic.

**Note**: The Apache Chainsaw deserialization vulnerability has been reported as **CVE-2020-9493** and affects EOL Apache Log4j **1.2.x** versions that include this component.Apache Log4j **1.2.x** versions are vulnerable to SQL injection (SQLi). This may allow an attacker to insert SQL queries into messages being logged that will get executed against a backend database. 

**Note:** This issue  affects versions **1.2.x** that are configured to use the `JDBCAppender`. The vendor states that Log4j 1 is no longer maintained and this issue will not be fixed.Log4j is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) due to the deserialization of untrusted data. An attacker that is able to make the JMSSink component submit requests to a given LDAP server could load malicious Java classes into the vulnerable application's memory by leveraging the JNDI class-loading capability.

In order to exploit this vulnerability, the attacker must be able to control the configuration of Log4j, or must have access to an LDAP server which the JMSSink component is configured to use. Log4j must also be configured to utilize JMSSink, which is not used by default.Apache chainsaw is vulnerable to a deserialization of untrusted data flaw. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause remote code execution (RCE).Log4j **1.x** versions are vulnerable to deserializing untrusted data if configured to use `JMSAppender` (which is not the default). A remote attacker could leverage this to execute arbitrary code on the underlying system with the privileges of the application that is running Log4j.

**Note** that Log4j **1.x** has been marked EOL for many years and has not received updates in this time.Apache Log4j is vulnerable to man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks due to improper SSL certificate validation due to host name mismatch. An attacker could exploit this by mounting a man-in-the-middle attack which could leak log messages sent through SMTPS.Apache Log4j is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE). Apache Log4j is vulnerable to a remote code execution (RCE) issue due to how the Apache Chainsaw component can unsafely deserialize user controlled input.

An attacker could send crafted input to the application in order to abuse the flaw and execute malicious code on the system.

**Note**: The Apache Chainsaw deserialization vulnerability has been reported as **CVE-2020-9493** and affects EOL Apache Log4j **1.2.x** versions that include this component.Apache Log4j **1.2.x** versions are vulnerable to SQL injection (SQLi). **Note:** This issue  affects versions **1.2.x** that are configured to use the `JDBCAppender`. In order to exploit this vulnerability, the attacker must be able to control the configuration of Log4j, or must have access to an LDAP server which the JMSSink component is configured to use. fullDescription.text:
Apache Log4j is vulnerable to man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks due to improper SSL certificate validation due to host name mismatch. An attacker could exploit this by mounting a man-in-the-middle attack which could leak log messages sent through SMTPS.Apache Log4j, as used in many popular services, is vulnerable to improperly allowing lightweight directory access protocol (LDAP) access via Java naming and directory interface (JNDI). A remote attacker able to supply the end application with specially crafted input that is then processed by the Log4j subcomponent could cause the execution of arbitrary Java code.

**Note** 

- log4j-api packages by themselves do not contain the vulnerable functionality and are therefore unaffected. log4j-core packages and the upstream overarching source repository are affected.

- A previously suggested mitigation of setting environment variable `LOG4J_FORMAT_MSG_NO_LOOKUPS=true` is not recommended. This mitigation has been proven inadequate against this vulnerability. 

- This vulnerability is partially fixed in [**2.15.0-rc2**](https://github.com/apache/logging-log4j2/releases/tag/log4j-2.15.0-rc2) by [this](https://github.com/apache/logging-log4j2/commit/001aaada7dab82c3c09cde5f8e14245dc9d8b454) commit and [this](https://github.com/apache/logging-log4j2/commit/bac0d8a35c7e354a0d3f706569116dff6c6bd658) commit. These fixes were deemed incomplete. See BDSA-2021-3779 (CVE-2021-45046) for more details.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).Apache log4j is vulnerable to a denial-of-service (DoS) when uncontrolled recursion occurs through a self-referencing lookup.  An attacker can trigger a DoS with malicious input data that generates a recursive lookup  and consequent application crash.

Successful attacks require the attacker to have access to Thread Context Map (MDC) input, and for log4j configured with non-default pattern layout with a Context Lookup.

Only the log4j-core JAR file is impacted by this vulnerability. Applications using only the log4j-api JAR file without the log4j-core JAR file are not impacted.

Apache Log4j is the only Logging Services subproject affected by this vulnerability. Other projects like Log4net  are not impacted.Apache Log4j contains a remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability. This allows an attacker that has permissions to modify the logging configuration files to input a malicious JDBC Appender with a data source referencing a JDNI URI. This can then lead to RCE.

**Note:** This vulnerability impacts log4j-core.

help.text:
Apache Log4j is vulnerable to man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks due to improper SSL certificate validation due to host name mismatch. An attacker could exploit this by mounting a man-in-the-middle attack which could leak log messages sent through SMTPS.Apache Log4j, as used in many popular services, is vulnerable to improperly allowing lightweight directory access protocol (LDAP) access via Java naming and directory interface (JNDI). A remote attacker able to supply the end application with specially crafted input that is then processed by the Log4j subcomponent could cause the execution of arbitrary Java code.

**Note** 

- log4j-api packages by themselves do not contain the vulnerable functionality and are therefore unaffected. log4j-core packages and the upstream overarching source repository are affected.

- A previously suggested mitigation of setting environment variable `LOG4J_FORMAT_MSG_NO_LOOKUPS=true` is not recommended. This mitigation has been proven inadequate against this vulnerability. 

- This vulnerability is partially fixed in [**2.15.0-rc2**](https://github.com/apache/logging-log4j2/releases/tag/log4j-2.15.0-rc2) by [this](https://github.com/apache/logging-log4j2/commit/001aaada7dab82c3c09cde5f8e14245dc9d8b454) commit and [this](https://github.com/apache/logging-log4j2/commit/bac0d8a35c7e354a0d3f706569116dff6c6bd658) commit. These fixes were deemed incomplete. See BDSA-2021-3779 (CVE-2021-45046) for more details.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).Apache log4j is vulnerable to a denial-of-service (DoS) when uncontrolled recursion occurs through a self-referencing lookup.  An attacker can trigger a DoS with malicious input data that generates a recursive lookup  and consequent application crash.

Successful attacks require the attacker to have access to Thread Context Map (MDC) input, and for log4j configured with non-default pattern layout with a Context Lookup.

Only the log4j-core JAR file is impacted by this vulnerability. Applications using only the log4j-api JAR file without the log4j-core JAR file are not impacted.

Apache Log4j is the only Logging Services subproject affected by this vulnerability. Other projects like Log4net  are not impacted.Apache Log4j contains a remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability. This allows an attacker that has permissions to modify the logging configuration files to input a malicious JDBC Appender with a data source referencing a JDNI URI. This can then lead to RCE.

**Note:** This vulnerability impacts log4j-core.

fullDescription.text:
Apache Struts contains an improper handling of URLs vulnerability within the Convention plug-in. This can be exploited by crafting special URLs to cause path traversal and arbitrary code execution.Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to code execution via parsing maliciously crafted XSLT files. An attacker able to upload such a file to the server, then view the file from the web server, can cause code execution in the context of the web server user or alter the application state.

**NOTE: Synopsys Security Team believe that additional versions of Apache Struts are vulnerable . The range of affected versions may be subject to change pending conclusion of Responsible Disclosure.**Apache Struts contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker is able to enter a null value for a URL field within the `URLValidator` class due to an overly permissive regular expression. This can lead to a crash.Apache Struts is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to improper validation of user-supplied input in form fields. An attacker could exploit this issue by crafting a malicious URL.Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to cross-site scripting when using versions of the Java Runtime Environment (JRE) with a broken implementation of `URLDecoder`.  This could allow an attacker to steal tokens, session cookies, credentials or other sensitive information.Apache Struts contains an information disclosure vulnerability due to improper use of the Config Browser plugin within a production environment. An attacker could exploit this to expose application information.Struts is vulnerable to remote command injection through incorrectly parsing a web client supplied invalid Content-Type, Content-Disposition or Content-Length headers. These commands get executed under the Apache Web user. This is full remote command execution and is being actively exploited in the wild from the initial disclosure.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).If Apache Struts takes an URL in a form field and the built-in `URLValidator` functionality is utilized, an attacker can craft special input which will overload the server process. This leads to a denial-of-service (DoS).An authenticated attacker can cause a denial of service when the application uses Spring AOP functionality to secure Struts action.The Struts 1 plug-in provides the ability to use existing Struts 1 Actions and Action forms within Struts 2 applications. Insufficient input validation within the `ActionMessage` class can lead to remote code execution (RCE).

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).A remote code execution (RCE) attack is possible when using the Struts REST plugin with `XStream` handler to deserialize XML requests.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).A denial-of-service (DoS) attack is possible when using outdated `XStream` library with the Struts REST plug-in for Apache Struts web framework.A denial-of-service (DoS) attack is possible against Apache Struts2 when using the `URLValidator` class to validate an `URL` provided in a form field.Apache Struts is prone to remote code execution (RCE) attack when using expressions in FreeMarker tags instead of string literals.Apache Struts is vulnerable to denial-of-service attack via REST plugin when utilizing XStream library to serilaize and deserialize XML objects.Apache Struts is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE).  This vulnerability only manifests in certain configuration environments.  This vulnerability allows a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on a vulnerable system with the privileges of the Apache Struts process.  This can lead to a total compromise of a systems confidentiality and integrity, and the possibility to cause a substantial availability impact also.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to RCE through forced double evaluation of powerful OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause remote code execution (RCE) in the context of the web server that hosts a vulnerable Struts2 application.Apache Struts2 contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This vulnerability requires an attacker to have the ability to upload a file to the server.  Under certain conditions, a remote attacker can then change the permissions of files and directories to read only.  This will prevent certain actions from working, causing errors.  This can be used to cause a denial-of-service.Apache Struts 2 is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) through forced OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause RCE in the context of the web server that hosts the vulnerable Struts application.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-31805** (**BDSA-2022-1011**).

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).Apache Struts 2 is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) through forced OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause RCE in the context of the web server that hosts the vulnerable Struts application.

**Note:** This vulnerability exists due to an incomplete fix for **CVE-2020-17530** (**BDSA-2020-3670**).Apache Struts contains an out-of-memory condition vulnerability due to insufficient validation of the sizes of non-file normal form fields in multipart requests. A privileged attacker could exploit this issue by passing a multipart request to a vulnerable instance which could trigger a denial-of-service (DoS) condition via excessive resource allocation.

Under certain conditions, a remote attacker can then change the permissions of files and directories to read only.  This will prevent certain actions from working, causing errors.  This can be used to cause a denial-of-service.Apache Struts 2 is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) through forced OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause RCE in the context of the web server that hosts the vulnerable Struts application.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-31805** (**BDSA-2022-1011**).

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).Apache Struts 2 is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) through forced OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause RCE in the context of the web server that hosts the vulnerable Struts application.

**Note:** This vulnerability exists due to an incomplete fix for **CVE-2020-17530** (**BDSA-2020-3670**).Apache Struts contains an out-of-memory condition vulnerability due to insufficient validation of the sizes of non-file normal form fields in multipart requests. A privileged attacker could exploit this issue by passing a multipart request to a vulnerable instance which could trigger a denial-of-service (DoS) condition via excessive resource allocation.

## Description
Apache Struts contains an improper handling of URLs vulnerability within the Convention plug-in. This can be exploited by crafting special URLs to cause path traversal and arbitrary code execution.Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to code execution via parsing maliciously crafted XSLT files. An attacker able to upload such a file to the server, then view the file from the web server, can cause code execution in the context of the web server user or alter the application state.

**NOTE: Synopsys Security Team believe that additional versions of Apache Struts are vulnerable . The range of affected versions may be subject to change pending conclusion of Responsible Disclosure.**Apache Struts contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker is able to enter a null value for a URL field within the `URLValidator` class due to an overly permissive regular expression. This can lead to a crash.Apache Struts is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to improper validation of user-supplied input in form fields. An attacker could exploit this issue by crafting a malicious URL.Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to cross-site scripting when using versions of the Java Runtime Environment (JRE) with a broken implementation of `URLDecoder`.  This could allow an attacker to steal tokens, session cookies, credentials or other sensitive information.Apache Struts contains an information disclosure vulnerability due to improper use of the Config Browser plugin within a production environment. An attacker could exploit this to expose application information.Struts is vulnerable to remote command injection through incorrectly parsing a web client supplied invalid Content-Type, Content-Disposition or Content-Length headers. These commands get executed under the Apache Web user. This is full remote command execution and is being actively exploited in the wild from the initial disclosure.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).If Apache Struts takes an URL in a form field and the built-in `URLValidator` functionality is utilized, an attacker can craft special input which will overload the server process. Insufficient input validation within the `ActionMessage` class can lead to remote code execution (RCE).

This vulnerability only manifests in certain configuration environments.  This vulnerability allows a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on a vulnerable system with the privileges of the Apache Struts process.  This can lead to a total compromise of a systems confidentiality and integrity, and the possibility to cause a substantial availability impact also.

help.text:
Apache Struts contains an improper handling of URLs vulnerability within the Convention plug-in. This can be exploited by crafting special URLs to cause path traversal and arbitrary code execution.Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to code execution via parsing maliciously crafted XSLT files. An attacker able to upload such a file to the server, then view the file from the web server, can cause code execution in the context of the web server user or alter the application state.

**NOTE: Synopsys Security Team believe that additional versions of Apache Struts are vulnerable . The range of affected versions may be subject to change pending conclusion of Responsible Disclosure.**Apache Struts contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker is able to enter a null value for a URL field within the `URLValidator` class due to an overly permissive regular expression. This can lead to a crash.Apache Struts is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to improper validation of user-supplied input in form fields. An attacker could exploit this issue by crafting a malicious URL.Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to cross-site scripting when using versions of the Java Runtime Environment (JRE) with a broken implementation of `URLDecoder`.  This could allow an attacker to steal tokens, session cookies, credentials or other sensitive information.Apache Struts contains an information disclosure vulnerability due to improper use of the Config Browser plugin within a production environment. An attacker could exploit this to expose application information.Struts is vulnerable to remote command injection through incorrectly parsing a web client supplied invalid Content-Type, Content-Disposition or Content-Length headers. These commands get executed under the Apache Web user. This is full remote command execution and is being actively exploited in the wild from the initial disclosure.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).If Apache Struts takes an URL in a form field and the built-in `URLValidator` functionality is utilized, an attacker can craft special input which will overload the server process. This leads to a denial-of-service (DoS).An authenticated attacker can cause a denial of service when the application uses Spring AOP functionality to secure Struts action.The Struts 1 plug-in provides the ability to use existing Struts 1 Actions and Action forms within Struts 2 applications. Insufficient input validation within the `ActionMessage` class can lead to remote code execution (RCE).

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).A remote code execution (RCE) attack is possible when using the Struts REST plugin with `XStream` handler to deserialize XML requests.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).A denial-of-service (DoS) attack is possible when using outdated `XStream` library with the Struts REST plug-in for Apache Struts web framework.A denial-of-service (DoS) attack is possible against Apache Struts2 when using the `URLValidator` class to validate an `URL` provided in a form field.Apache Struts is prone to remote code execution (RCE) attack when using expressions in FreeMarker tags instead of string literals.Apache Struts is vulnerable to denial-of-service attack via REST plugin when utilizing XStream library to serilaize and deserialize XML objects.Apache Struts is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE).  This vulnerability only manifests in certain configuration environments.  This vulnerability allows a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on a vulnerable system with the privileges of the Apache Struts process.  This can lead to a total compromise of a systems confidentiality and integrity, and the possibility to cause a substantial availability impact also.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to RCE through forced double evaluation of powerful OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause remote code execution (RCE) in the context of the web server that hosts a vulnerable Struts2 application.Apache Struts2 contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This vulnerability requires an attacker to have the ability to upload a file to the server.  Under certain conditions, a remote attacker can then change the permissions of files and directories to read only.  This will prevent certain actions from working, causing errors.  This can be used to cause a denial-of-service.Apache Struts 2 is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) through forced OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause RCE in the context of the web server that hosts the vulnerable Struts application.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-31805** (**BDSA-2022-1011**).

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).Apache Struts 2 is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) through forced OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause RCE in the context of the web server that hosts the vulnerable Struts application.

**Note:** This vulnerability exists due to an incomplete fix for **CVE-2020-17530** (**BDSA-2020-3670**).Apache Struts contains an out-of-memory condition vulnerability due to insufficient validation of the sizes of non-file normal form fields in multipart requests. A privileged attacker could exploit this issue by passing a multipart request to a vulnerable instance which could trigger a denial-of-service (DoS) condition via excessive resource allocation.

This can lead to a crash.Apache Struts is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to improper validation of user-supplied input in form fields. An attacker could exploit this issue by crafting a malicious URL.Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to cross-site scripting when using versions of the Java Runtime Environment (JRE) with a broken implementation of `URLDecoder`.  This could allow an attacker to steal tokens, session cookies, credentials or other sensitive information.Apache Struts contains an information disclosure vulnerability due to improper use of the Config Browser plugin within a production environment. An attacker could exploit this to expose application information.Struts is vulnerable to remote command injection through incorrectly parsing a web client supplied invalid Content-Type, Content-Disposition or Content-Length headers. These commands get executed under the Apache Web user. This is full remote command execution and is being actively exploited in the wild from the initial disclosure.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).If Apache Struts takes an URL in a form field and the built-in `URLValidator` functionality is utilized, an attacker can craft special input which will overload the server process. This leads to a denial-of-service (DoS).An authenticated attacker can cause a denial of service when the application uses Spring AOP functionality to secure Struts action.The Struts 1 plug-in provides the ability to use existing Struts 1 Actions and Action forms within Struts 2 applications. Insufficient input validation within the `ActionMessage` class can lead to remote code execution (RCE).

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).A remote code execution (RCE) attack is possible when using the Struts REST plugin with `XStream` handler to deserialize XML requests.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).A denial-of-service (DoS) attack is possible when using outdated `XStream` library with the Struts REST plug-in for Apache Struts web framework.A denial-of-service (DoS) attack is possible against Apache Struts2 when using the `URLValidator` class to validate an `URL` provided in a form field.Apache Struts is prone to remote code execution (RCE) attack when using expressions in FreeMarker tags instead of string literals.Apache Struts is vulnerable to denial-of-service attack via REST plugin when utilizing XStream library to serilaize and deserialize XML objects.Apache Struts is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE).  This vulnerability only manifests in certain configuration environments.  This vulnerability allows a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on a vulnerable system with the privileges of the Apache Struts process.  This can lead to a total compromise of a systems confidentiality and integrity, and the possibility to cause a substantial availability impact also.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to RCE through forced double evaluation of powerful OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause remote code execution (RCE) in the context of the web server that hosts a vulnerable Struts2 application.Apache Struts2 contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This vulnerability requires an attacker to have the ability to upload a file to the server.  Under certain conditions, a remote attacker can then change the permissions of files and directories to read only.  This will prevent certain actions from working, causing errors.  This can be used to cause a denial-of-service.Apache Struts 2 is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) through forced OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause RCE in the context of the web server that hosts the vulnerable Struts application.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-31805** (**BDSA-2022-1011**).

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).Apache Struts 2 is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) through forced OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause RCE in the context of the web server that hosts the vulnerable Struts application.

**Note:** This vulnerability exists due to an incomplete fix for **CVE-2020-17530** (**BDSA-2020-3670**).Apache Struts contains an out-of-memory condition vulnerability due to insufficient validation of the sizes of non-file normal form fields in multipart requests. A privileged attacker could exploit this issue by passing a multipart request to a vulnerable instance which could trigger a denial-of-service (DoS) condition via excessive resource allocation.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).A denial-of-service (DoS) attack is possible when using outdated `XStream` library with the Struts REST plug-in for Apache Struts web framework.A denial-of-service (DoS) attack is possible against Apache Struts2 when using the `URLValidator` class to validate an `URL` provided in a form field.Apache Struts is prone to remote code execution (RCE) attack when using expressions in FreeMarker tags instead of string literals.Apache Struts is vulnerable to denial-of-service attack via REST plugin when utilizing XStream library to serilaize and deserialize XML objects.Apache Struts is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE).  This vulnerability only manifests in certain configuration environments.  This vulnerability allows a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on a vulnerable system with the privileges of the Apache Struts process.  This can lead to a total compromise of a systems confidentiality and integrity, and the possibility to cause a substantial availability impact also.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to RCE through forced double evaluation of powerful OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause remote code execution (RCE) in the context of the web server that hosts a vulnerable Struts2 application.Apache Struts2 contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This vulnerability requires an attacker to have the ability to upload a file to the server.  Under certain conditions, a remote attacker can then change the permissions of files and directories to read only.  This will prevent certain actions from working, causing errors.  This can be used to cause a denial-of-service.Apache Struts 2 is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) through forced OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause RCE in the context of the web server that hosts the vulnerable Struts application.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-31805** (**BDSA-2022-1011**).

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).Apache Struts 2 is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) through forced OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause RCE in the context of the web server that hosts the vulnerable Struts application.

**Note:** This vulnerability exists due to an incomplete fix for **CVE-2020-17530** (**BDSA-2020-3670**).Apache Struts contains an out-of-memory condition vulnerability due to insufficient validation of the sizes of non-file normal form fields in multipart requests. A privileged attacker could exploit this issue by passing a multipart request to a vulnerable instance which could trigger a denial-of-service (DoS) condition via excessive resource allocation.

Short Term  2.5.32

Long Term 6.3.0.1

help.text:
Apache Struts contains an improper handling of URLs vulnerability within the Convention plug-in. This can be exploited by crafting special URLs to cause path traversal and arbitrary code execution.Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to code execution via parsing maliciously crafted XSLT files. An attacker able to upload such a file to the server, then view the file from the web server, can cause code execution in the context of the web server user or alter the application state.

**NOTE: Synopsys Security Team believe that additional versions of Apache Struts are vulnerable . The range of affected versions may be subject to change pending conclusion of Responsible Disclosure.**Apache Struts contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker is able to enter a null value for a URL field within the `URLValidator` class due to an overly permissive regular expression. This can lead to a crash.Apache Struts is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to improper validation of user-supplied input in form fields. An attacker could exploit this issue by crafting a malicious URL.Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to cross-site scripting when using versions of the Java Runtime Environment (JRE) with a broken implementation of `URLDecoder`.  This could allow an attacker to steal tokens, session cookies, credentials or other sensitive information.Apache Struts contains an information disclosure vulnerability due to improper use of the Config Browser plugin within a production environment. An attacker could exploit this to expose application information.Struts is vulnerable to remote command injection through incorrectly parsing a web client supplied invalid Content-Type, Content-Disposition or Content-Length headers. These commands get executed under the Apache Web user. This is full remote command execution and is being actively exploited in the wild from the initial disclosure.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).If Apache Struts takes an URL in a form field and the built-in `URLValidator` functionality is utilized, an attacker can craft special input which will overload the server process. This leads to a denial-of-service (DoS).An authenticated attacker can cause a denial of service when the application uses Spring AOP functionality to secure Struts action.The Struts 1 plug-in provides the ability to use existing Struts 1 Actions and Action forms within Struts 2 applications. This vulnerability only manifests in certain configuration environments. This can lead to a total compromise of a systems confidentiality and integrity, and the possibility to cause a substantial availability impact also.

This can be used to cause a denial-of-service.Apache Struts 2 is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) through forced OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. Insufficient input validation within the `ActionMessage` class can lead to remote code execution (RCE).

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).A remote code execution (RCE) attack is possible when using the Struts REST plugin with `XStream` handler to deserialize XML requests.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).A denial-of-service (DoS) attack is possible when using outdated `XStream` library with the Struts REST plug-in for Apache Struts web framework.A denial-of-service (DoS) attack is possible against Apache Struts2 when using the `URLValidator` class to validate an `URL` provided in a form field.Apache Struts is prone to remote code execution (RCE) attack when using expressions in FreeMarker tags instead of string literals.Apache Struts is vulnerable to denial-of-service attack via REST plugin when utilizing XStream library to serilaize and deserialize XML objects.Apache Struts is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE).  This vulnerability only manifests in certain configuration environments.  This vulnerability allows a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on a vulnerable system with the privileges of the Apache Struts process.  This can lead to a total compromise of a systems confidentiality and integrity, and the possibility to cause a substantial availability impact also.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to RCE through forced double evaluation of powerful OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause remote code execution (RCE) in the context of the web server that hosts a vulnerable Struts2 application.Apache Struts2 contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This vulnerability requires an attacker to have the ability to upload a file to the server.  Under certain conditions, a remote attacker can then change the permissions of files and directories to read only.  This will prevent certain actions from working, causing errors.  This can be used to cause a denial-of-service.Apache Struts 2 is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) through forced OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause RCE in the context of the web server that hosts the vulnerable Struts application.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-31805** (**BDSA-2022-1011**).

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).Apache Struts 2 is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) through forced OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause RCE in the context of the web server that hosts the vulnerable Struts application.

**Note:** This vulnerability exists due to an incomplete fix for **CVE-2020-17530** (**BDSA-2020-3670**).Apache Struts contains an out-of-memory condition vulnerability due to insufficient validation of the sizes of non-file normal form fields in multipart requests. A privileged attacker could exploit this issue by passing a multipart request to a vulnerable instance which could trigger a denial-of-service (DoS) condition via excessive resource allocation.

An attacker could exploit this issue by crafting a malicious URL.Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to cross-site scripting when using versions of the Java Runtime Environment (JRE) with a broken implementation of `URLDecoder`. This can lead to a total compromise of a systems confidentiality and integrity, and the possibility to cause a substantial availability impact also.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to RCE through forced double evaluation of powerful OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause remote code execution (RCE) in the context of the web server that hosts a vulnerable Struts2 application.Apache Struts2 contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This vulnerability requires an attacker to have the ability to upload a file to the server.  Under certain conditions, a remote attacker can then change the permissions of files and directories to read only.  This will prevent certain actions from working, causing errors.  This can be used to cause a denial-of-service.Apache Struts 2 is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) through forced OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause RCE in the context of the web server that hosts the vulnerable Struts application.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-31805** (**BDSA-2022-1011**).

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).Apache Struts 2 is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) through forced OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause RCE in the context of the web server that hosts the vulnerable Struts application.

**Note:** This vulnerability exists due to an incomplete fix for **CVE-2020-17530** (**BDSA-2020-3670**).Apache Struts contains an out-of-memory condition vulnerability due to insufficient validation of the sizes of non-file normal form fields in multipart requests. A privileged attacker could exploit this issue by passing a multipart request to a vulnerable instance which could trigger a denial-of-service (DoS) condition via excessive resource allocation.

An attacker is able to enter a null value for a URL field within the `URLValidator` class due to an overly permissive regular expression. This can lead to a crash.Apache Struts is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to improper validation of user-supplied input in form fields. An attacker could exploit this issue by crafting a malicious URL.Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to cross-site scripting when using versions of the Java Runtime Environment (JRE) with a broken implementation of `URLDecoder`.  This could allow an attacker to steal tokens, session cookies, credentials or other sensitive information.Apache Struts contains an information disclosure vulnerability due to improper use of the Config Browser plugin within a production environment. An attacker could exploit this to expose application information.Struts is vulnerable to remote command injection through incorrectly parsing a web client supplied invalid Content-Type, Content-Disposition or Content-Length headers. These commands get executed under the Apache Web user. This is full remote command execution and is being actively exploited in the wild from the initial disclosure.

help.text:
Apache Struts contains an improper handling of URLs vulnerability within the Convention plug-in. This can be exploited by crafting special URLs to cause path traversal and arbitrary code execution.Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to code execution via parsing maliciously crafted XSLT files. An attacker able to upload such a file to the server, then view the file from the web server, can cause code execution in the context of the web server user or alter the application state.

**NOTE: Synopsys Security Team believe that additional versions of Apache Struts are vulnerable . The range of affected versions may be subject to change pending conclusion of Responsible Disclosure.**Apache Struts contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker is able to enter a null value for a URL field within the `URLValidator` class due to an overly permissive regular expression. This can lead to a crash.Apache Struts is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to improper validation of user-supplied input in form fields. An attacker could exploit this issue by crafting a malicious URL.Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to cross-site scripting when using versions of the Java Runtime Environment (JRE) with a broken implementation of `URLDecoder`.  This could allow an attacker to steal tokens, session cookies, credentials or other sensitive information.Apache Struts contains an information disclosure vulnerability due to improper use of the Config Browser plugin within a production environment. An attacker could exploit this to expose application information.Struts is vulnerable to remote command injection through incorrectly parsing a web client supplied invalid Content-Type, Content-Disposition or Content-Length headers. These commands get executed under the Apache Web user. This is full remote command execution and is being actively exploited in the wild from the initial disclosure.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).If Apache Struts takes an URL in a form field and the built-in `URLValidator` functionality is utilized, an attacker can craft special input which will overload the server process. This leads to a denial-of-service (DoS).An authenticated attacker can cause a denial of service when the application uses Spring AOP functionality to secure Struts action.The Struts 1 plug-in provides the ability to use existing Struts 1 Actions and Action forms within Struts 2 applications. Insufficient input validation within the `ActionMessage` class can lead to remote code execution (RCE).

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).A remote code execution (RCE) attack is possible when using the Struts REST plugin with `XStream` handler to deserialize XML requests.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).A denial-of-service (DoS) attack is possible when using outdated `XStream` library with the Struts REST plug-in for Apache Struts web framework.A denial-of-service (DoS) attack is possible against Apache Struts2 when using the `URLValidator` class to validate an `URL` provided in a form field.Apache Struts is prone to remote code execution (RCE) attack when using expressions in FreeMarker tags instead of string literals.Apache Struts is vulnerable to denial-of-service attack via REST plugin when utilizing XStream library to serilaize and deserialize XML objects.Apache Struts is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE).  This vulnerability only manifests in certain configuration environments.  This vulnerability allows a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on a vulnerable system with the privileges of the Apache Struts process.  This can lead to a total compromise of a systems confidentiality and integrity, and the possibility to cause a substantial availability impact also.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to RCE through forced double evaluation of powerful OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause remote code execution (RCE) in the context of the web server that hosts a vulnerable Struts2 application.Apache Struts2 contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This vulnerability requires an attacker to have the ability to upload a file to the server.  Under certain conditions, a remote attacker can then change the permissions of files and directories to read only.  This will prevent certain actions from working, causing errors.  This can be used to cause a denial-of-service.Apache Struts 2 is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) through forced OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause RCE in the context of the web server that hosts the vulnerable Struts application.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-31805** (**BDSA-2022-1011**).

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).Apache Struts 2 is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) through forced OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause RCE in the context of the web server that hosts the vulnerable Struts application.

**Note:** This vulnerability exists due to an incomplete fix for **CVE-2020-17530** (**BDSA-2020-3670**).Apache Struts contains an out-of-memory condition vulnerability due to insufficient validation of the sizes of non-file normal form fields in multipart requests. A privileged attacker could exploit this issue by passing a multipart request to a vulnerable instance which could trigger a denial-of-service (DoS) condition via excessive resource allocation.

The range of affected versions may be subject to change pending conclusion of Responsible Disclosure.**Apache Struts contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker is able to enter a null value for a URL field within the `URLValidator` class due to an overly permissive regular expression. This can lead to a crash.Apache Struts is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to improper validation of user-supplied input in form fields. An attacker could exploit this issue by crafting a malicious URL.Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to cross-site scripting when using versions of the Java Runtime Environment (JRE) with a broken implementation of `URLDecoder`.  This could allow an attacker to steal tokens, session cookies, credentials or other sensitive information.Apache Struts contains an information disclosure vulnerability due to improper use of the Config Browser plugin within a production environment. An attacker could exploit this to expose application information.Struts is vulnerable to remote command injection through incorrectly parsing a web client supplied invalid Content-Type, Content-Disposition or Content-Length headers. These commands get executed under the Apache Web user. This is full remote command execution and is being actively exploited in the wild from the initial disclosure.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).If Apache Struts takes an URL in a form field and the built-in `URLValidator` functionality is utilized, an attacker can craft special input which will overload the server process. This leads to a denial-of-service (DoS).An authenticated attacker can cause a denial of service when the application uses Spring AOP functionality to secure Struts action.The Struts 1 plug-in provides the ability to use existing Struts 1 Actions and Action forms within Struts 2 applications. Insufficient input validation within the `ActionMessage` class can lead to remote code execution (RCE).

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).A remote code execution (RCE) attack is possible when using the Struts REST plugin with `XStream` handler to deserialize XML requests.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).A denial-of-service (DoS) attack is possible when using outdated `XStream` library with the Struts REST plug-in for Apache Struts web framework.A denial-of-service (DoS) attack is possible against Apache Struts2 when using the `URLValidator` class to validate an `URL` provided in a form field.Apache Struts is prone to remote code execution (RCE) attack when using expressions in FreeMarker tags instead of string literals.Apache Struts is vulnerable to denial-of-service attack via REST plugin when utilizing XStream library to serilaize and deserialize XML objects.Apache Struts is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE).  This vulnerability only manifests in certain configuration environments.  This vulnerability allows a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on a vulnerable system with the privileges of the Apache Struts process.  This can lead to a total compromise of a systems confidentiality and integrity, and the possibility to cause a substantial availability impact also.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to RCE through forced double evaluation of powerful OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause remote code execution (RCE) in the context of the web server that hosts a vulnerable Struts2 application.Apache Struts2 contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This vulnerability requires an attacker to have the ability to upload a file to the server.  Under certain conditions, a remote attacker can then change the permissions of files and directories to read only.  This will prevent certain actions from working, causing errors.  This can be used to cause a denial-of-service.Apache Struts 2 is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) through forced OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause RCE in the context of the web server that hosts the vulnerable Struts application.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-31805** (**BDSA-2022-1011**).

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).Apache Struts 2 is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) through forced OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause RCE in the context of the web server that hosts the vulnerable Struts application.

**Note:** This vulnerability exists due to an incomplete fix for **CVE-2020-17530** (**BDSA-2020-3670**).Apache Struts contains an out-of-memory condition vulnerability due to insufficient validation of the sizes of non-file normal form fields in multipart requests. A privileged attacker could exploit this issue by passing a multipart request to a vulnerable instance which could trigger a denial-of-service (DoS) condition via excessive resource allocation.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).A denial-of-service (DoS) attack is possible when using outdated `XStream` library with the Struts REST plug-in for Apache Struts web framework.A denial-of-service (DoS) attack is possible against Apache Struts2 when using the `URLValidator` class to validate an `URL` provided in a form field.Apache Struts is prone to remote code execution (RCE) attack when using expressions in FreeMarker tags instead of string literals.Apache Struts is vulnerable to denial-of-service attack via REST plugin when utilizing XStream library to serilaize and deserialize XML objects.Apache Struts is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE).  This vulnerability only manifests in certain configuration environments.  This vulnerability allows a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on a vulnerable system with the privileges of the Apache Struts process.  This can lead to a total compromise of a systems confidentiality and integrity, and the possibility to cause a substantial availability impact also.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to RCE through forced double evaluation of powerful OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause remote code execution (RCE) in the context of the web server that hosts a vulnerable Struts2 application.Apache Struts2 contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This vulnerability requires an attacker to have the ability to upload a file to the server.  Under certain conditions, a remote attacker can then change the permissions of files and directories to read only.  This will prevent certain actions from working, causing errors.  This can be used to cause a denial-of-service.Apache Struts 2 is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) through forced OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause RCE in the context of the web server that hosts the vulnerable Struts application.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-31805** (**BDSA-2022-1011**).

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).Apache Struts 2 is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) through forced OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause RCE in the context of the web server that hosts the vulnerable Struts application.

**Note:** This vulnerability exists due to an incomplete fix for **CVE-2020-17530** (**BDSA-2020-3670**).Apache Struts contains an out-of-memory condition vulnerability due to insufficient validation of the sizes of non-file normal form fields in multipart requests. A privileged attacker could exploit this issue by passing a multipart request to a vulnerable instance which could trigger a denial-of-service (DoS) condition via excessive resource allocation.

Short Term  2.5.32

Long Term 6.3.0.1

help.text:
Apache Struts contains an improper handling of URLs vulnerability within the Convention plug-in. This can be exploited by crafting special URLs to cause path traversal and arbitrary code execution.Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to code execution via parsing maliciously crafted XSLT files. An attacker able to upload such a file to the server, then view the file from the web server, can cause code execution in the context of the web server user or alter the application state.

**NOTE: Synopsys Security Team believe that additional versions of Apache Struts are vulnerable . The range of affected versions may be subject to change pending conclusion of Responsible Disclosure.**Apache Struts contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker is able to enter a null value for a URL field within the `URLValidator` class due to an overly permissive regular expression. This can lead to a crash.Apache Struts is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to improper validation of user-supplied input in form fields. An attacker could exploit this issue by crafting a malicious URL.Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to cross-site scripting when using versions of the Java Runtime Environment (JRE) with a broken implementation of `URLDecoder`.  This could allow an attacker to steal tokens, session cookies, credentials or other sensitive information.Apache Struts contains an information disclosure vulnerability due to improper use of the Config Browser plugin within a production environment. An attacker could exploit this to expose application information.Struts is vulnerable to remote command injection through incorrectly parsing a web client supplied invalid Content-Type, Content-Disposition or Content-Length headers. These commands get executed under the Apache Web user. This is full remote command execution and is being actively exploited in the wild from the initial disclosure.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).If Apache Struts takes an URL in a form field and the built-in `URLValidator` functionality is utilized, an attacker can craft special input which will overload the server process. This leads to a denial-of-service (DoS).An authenticated attacker can cause a denial of service when the application uses Spring AOP functionality to secure Struts action.The Struts 1 plug-in provides the ability to use existing Struts 1 Actions and Action forms within Struts 2 applications. This vulnerability only manifests in certain configuration environments. This can lead to a total compromise of a systems confidentiality and integrity, and the possibility to cause a substantial availability impact also.

This can be used to cause a denial-of-service.Apache Struts 2 is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) through forced OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. Insufficient input validation within the `ActionMessage` class can lead to remote code execution (RCE).

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).A remote code execution (RCE) attack is possible when using the Struts REST plugin with `XStream` handler to deserialize XML requests.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).A denial-of-service (DoS) attack is possible when using outdated `XStream` library with the Struts REST plug-in for Apache Struts web framework.A denial-of-service (DoS) attack is possible against Apache Struts2 when using the `URLValidator` class to validate an `URL` provided in a form field.Apache Struts is prone to remote code execution (RCE) attack when using expressions in FreeMarker tags instead of string literals.Apache Struts is vulnerable to denial-of-service attack via REST plugin when utilizing XStream library to serilaize and deserialize XML objects.Apache Struts is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE).  This vulnerability only manifests in certain configuration environments.  This vulnerability allows a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on a vulnerable system with the privileges of the Apache Struts process.  This can lead to a total compromise of a systems confidentiality and integrity, and the possibility to cause a substantial availability impact also.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to RCE through forced double evaluation of powerful OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause remote code execution (RCE) in the context of the web server that hosts a vulnerable Struts2 application.Apache Struts2 contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This vulnerability requires an attacker to have the ability to upload a file to the server.  Under certain conditions, a remote attacker can then change the permissions of files and directories to read only.  This will prevent certain actions from working, causing errors.  This can be used to cause a denial-of-service.Apache Struts 2 is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) through forced OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause RCE in the context of the web server that hosts the vulnerable Struts application.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-31805** (**BDSA-2022-1011**).

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).Apache Struts 2 is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) through forced OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause RCE in the context of the web server that hosts the vulnerable Struts application.

**Note:** This vulnerability exists due to an incomplete fix for **CVE-2020-17530** (**BDSA-2020-3670**).Apache Struts contains an out-of-memory condition vulnerability due to insufficient validation of the sizes of non-file normal form fields in multipart requests. A privileged attacker could exploit this issue by passing a multipart request to a vulnerable instance which could trigger a denial-of-service (DoS) condition via excessive resource allocation.

An attacker could exploit this issue by crafting a malicious URL.Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to cross-site scripting when using versions of the Java Runtime Environment (JRE) with a broken implementation of `URLDecoder`. This can lead to a total compromise of a systems confidentiality and integrity, and the possibility to cause a substantial availability impact also.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to RCE through forced double evaluation of powerful OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause remote code execution (RCE) in the context of the web server that hosts a vulnerable Struts2 application.Apache Struts2 contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This vulnerability requires an attacker to have the ability to upload a file to the server.  Under certain conditions, a remote attacker can then change the permissions of files and directories to read only.  This will prevent certain actions from working, causing errors.  This can be used to cause a denial-of-service.Apache Struts 2 is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) through forced OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause RCE in the context of the web server that hosts the vulnerable Struts application.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-31805** (**BDSA-2022-1011**).

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).Apache Struts 2 is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) through forced OGNL expression statements under certain circumstances. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause RCE in the context of the web server that hosts the vulnerable Struts application.

**Note:** This vulnerability exists due to an incomplete fix for **CVE-2020-17530** (**BDSA-2020-3670**).Apache Struts contains an out-of-memory condition vulnerability due to insufficient validation of the sizes of non-file normal form fields in multipart requests. A privileged attacker could exploit this issue by passing a multipart request to a vulnerable instance which could trigger a denial-of-service (DoS) condition via excessive resource allocation.

An attacker is able to enter a null value for a URL field within the `URLValidator` class due to an overly permissive regular expression. This can lead to a crash.Apache Struts is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to improper validation of user-supplied input in form fields. An attacker could exploit this issue by crafting a malicious URL.Apache Struts2 is vulnerable to cross-site scripting when using versions of the Java Runtime Environment (JRE) with a broken implementation of `URLDecoder`.  This could allow an attacker to steal tokens, session cookies, credentials or other sensitive information.Apache Struts contains an information disclosure vulnerability due to improper use of the Config Browser plugin within a production environment. An attacker could exploit this to expose application information.Struts is vulnerable to remote command injection through incorrectly parsing a web client supplied invalid Content-Type, Content-Disposition or Content-Length headers. These commands get executed under the Apache Web user. This is full remote command execution and is being actively exploited in the wild from the initial disclosure.
